etymology.description: Indicative of the position on the forearm where the pulse is palpated (寸口); the unit sense derives from the wrist-to-point distance. Compare 又, 手, 九, 爪.
etymology.interpretation: Depicts a wrist/hand with a small mark showing the pulse point (寸口). From the short span used to locate that point, it generalized to the unit meaning “inch,” and as a component it often relates to hand/action or small measures.

examples.chinese: 这块木板只有三寸厚(這塊木板只有三寸厚)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè kuài mùbǎn zhǐyǒu sān cùn hòu.
examples.english: This plank is only three inches thick.

examples.chinese: 医生在我的寸口上按脉(醫生在我的寸口上按脈)。
examples.pinyin: Yīshēng zài wǒ de cùnkǒu shàng àn mài.
examples.english: The doctor presses my pulse at the cun point.

examples.chinese: 城市里寸土寸金(城市裡寸土寸金)。
examples.pinyin: Chéngshì lǐ cùn tǔ cùn jīn.
examples.english: In the city, every inch of land is as precious as gold.
